guide.title: Gentoo Guide to USE flags
guide.author: John Davis
guide.abstract: This guide introduces you to the ultimate tool for customizing Gentoo -- USE settings. Not only is there a description of each USE flag in current use, there is also a helpful guide to help you to determine which USE flags you will need to use.

section.title: What is the use of USE flags anyway?

body.p: One of the things which attracted me, as a user, to Gentoo was the fact that it is a highly customisable distribution. The fact that it is a source based distribution allows the user complete control over what kinds of features and support are built in to the installed applications. Moreover, the idea of bloat reduction appealed to me -- I like not having to install things which I do not really need.

And how, exactly, does Gentoo achieve this? By defining USE settings. Essentially, these are keywords that define options used on a system-wide basis to configure applications during their respective compilation procedures.
Of course, Gentoo defines a set of safe default flags for you. You will find these in your /etc/make.profile/make.defaults file.
From the Gentoo-1.4_rc2 release, the USE settings are:
body.pre: USE="xv slang readline gpm berkdb mmx 3dnow gdbm tcpd pam libwww ssl nls arts perl python esd gif imlib sdl oggvorbis gnome gtk X qt kde motif opengl avi png tiff gif"
body.warn: Do not write to this file, as I can see many of you scrambling to do, but read the next section first.

body.p: To set you own use flags, edit your /etc/make.conf file. In that file, you will see:

Simply uncomment this line by removing the #, and add whatever other flags you want to add. "But what if I want to remove things from the make.defaults file?" I hear you ask. That is simply done by putting "-flag" in the USE variable in your /etc/make.conf file.
body.impo: Remember that -flag disables a flag and flag adds a flag. If a flag is neither in /etc/make.profile/make.defaults nor in /etc/make.conf then its functionality is disabled.
body.pre: USE="-gnome -kde qt -arts -nls python perl oggvorbis opengl sdl -postgres jpeg png truetype xml xml2 dvd avi aalib mpeg encode fbcon mmx"
body.p: You do not have to edit your /etc/make.conf if you want to emerge a single package with different USE flags. You can simply set the USE environment variable. Its contents are added to what you already have in make.defaults and make.conf. However, this "altered" USE flag isn't used when you update that package.
body.pre:
# USE="-guile +libgda" emerge -pv gnumeric
These are the packages that I would merge, in order:
Calculating dependencies ...done! [ebuild U ] app-office/gnumeric-1.0.13-r1 [1.0.8] +libgda -gb -evo +python +bonobo -guile -perl
# emerge -pv gnumeric
These are the packages that I would merge, in order:
Calculating dependencies ...done! [ebuild U ] app-office/gnumeric-1.0.13-r1 [1.0.8] -libgda -gb -evo +python +bonobo +guile -perl
body.note: As you can see emerge -pv pkg tells you which flags a certain package uses and what flags are set.
body.p: Now that you know how to enable extra flags, and disable existing flags, let us examine what these flags actually do.

body.note: If you want to add a use flag, add it to use.desc and upload it to CVS. use.desc is what this list is generated from.
body.p: You can find an automagically updated database of USE flags here: USE Flags.

etcat from the gentoolkit package will tell you which USE flags are available for a package, which USE flags are currently set, and which USE flags were set when the package was last emerged. It will also display a short description of these USE flags.
body.pre:
# etcat -u gnumeric [ Colour Code : set unset ] [ Legend : (U) Col 1 - Current USE flags ] [ : (I) Col 2 - Installed With USE flags ]
U I [ Found these USE variables in : app-office/gnumeric-1.0.13-r1 ] - - libgda : Adds GNU Data Access (CORBA wrapper) support for gnumeric - - gb : Adds support for Gnome Basic to gnumeric - + evo : Adds support for evolution in gnumeric + + python : Adds support/bindings for the Python language + + bonobo : Adds support for gnome-base/bonobo (Gnome CORBA interfaces) + + guile : Adds support for dev-util/guile (interpreter for Scheme) - + perl : Adds support/bindings for the Perl language.

body.p: For any feedback regarding the USE flags, please fill out a bug report at http://bugs.gentoo.org and assign it to seemant@gentoo.org
